oai_dc:dc.dc:title: MODELING BEACH PROFILE EVOLUTION - A STATISTICAL-PROCESS BASED APPROACH
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pender, Douglas
Karunarathna, Harshinie
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: extreme storm statistics
XBeach
erosion and accretion
morphodynamics
medium-term beach change
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents a new combined statistical-process based approach for modeling storm driven, cross-shore beach profile response. The approach discussed here involves combining detailed statistical modeling of offshore storm data and a process based morphodynamic model (XBeach), to assess the medium to long-term morphodynamic response of cross-shore beach profiles. Up until now the use of process-based models has been curtailed at the storm event timescale. This approach allows inclusion of the post-storm recovery, in addition to individual event impacts, thus allowing longer-term predictions. The calibration of XBeach for modeling, both, storm induced erosion and post- storm recovery, taking Narrabeen Beach, NSW, Australia as a case study; and the approach used to combine XBeach with the statistical framework to develop the approach are discussed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 33 (2012): Proceedings of 33rd Conference on Coastal Engineering, Santander, Spain, 2012; sediment.13
